titleInfo.title: Lieut. George Ratterman Tells of Hun Prison Camps, Tarbox School Students in WWI Scrapbook, Banner Newspaper, 1918

location.physicalLocation: Metropolitan Nashville/Davidson County Archives, Nashville Public Library

mods.abstract: A newspaper article featured in a scrapbook about the World War I military service of students of the Tarbox School, Nashville, Tennessee. The article was published in the Nashville Banner, after an interview with the WWI Nashville Aviator: “Lieut. George Ratterman Tells of Hun Prison Camps: Nashville Aviator Captured When Forced to Land on Disastrous Bombing Expedition Near Coblenz--Landshut ‘One Heluva Place.’” George H. Ratterman was born 1898 in Nashville, Tennessee. He attended Tarbox School, and during World War I served as 1st Lieutenant in the 96th Aero Squadron, United States Army. This unit fought on the Western Front during World War I. Ratterman, an aviator was “captured in Germany and placed in a prison camp in Rastatt in Baden, later to Karlshrue, in Baden, still later to Landshut, in Bavaria, and finally to the permanent American officers prison camp at Villingen in Baden.” Forms part of the Tarbox School Students in WWI Scrapbook.

titleInfo.title: Tarbox School Students in WWI Scrapbook
